comments: a(n) is the number of n-permutations in which all cycles have length two or three. [From Geoffrey Critzer, Feb 21 2010]
references: Miklos Bona, A Walk Through Combinatorics, World Scientific Publishing Co., 2002, page 169. [From _Geoffrey Critzer_, Feb 21 2010]
example: a(4)= 3 because there are 3 permutations of {1,2,3,4} that have cycle length two or three: (1,2)(3,4);(1,3)(2,4);(1,4)(2,3). [From Geoffrey Critzer, Feb 21 2010]
mathematica: Drop[CoefficientList[Series[Exp[x^2/2 + x^3/3], {x, 0, 20}], x]* Table[n!, {n, 0, 20}], 1] [From Geoffrey Critzer, Feb 21 2010]
author: _Karol A. Penson_, Mar 05 2003
extensions: Improved definition as proposed by _Joerg Arndt_ - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 23 2009
